title: How to Cook a Casserole

steps.headline: Peel and dice the onion and the garlic in to fine cubes
Chop the mushrooms in half lengthways (or if using small mushrooms you can leave them whole)
Place your pan on a medium heat, with a tablespoon of cooking oil in it.
steps.description: When the oil is moderately hot (see tips below), add the onion and garlic to the pan.

steps.headline: Stir the onion and garlic until they appear light brown and feel soft with the end of the spoon.
Add the meat and spread it evenly around the pan.
steps.description: Stir this occasionally for the next 5 minutes. The aim is to seal the meat so it looks darker on the outside.

steps.headline: Drain the water from the can of beans and add them to the pan, with the mushrooms and any other vegetables you are using.
Add the stock and red wine to the pan.
steps.description: Ideally the liquid should only just cover all of the ingredients but you can top it up with cold water if not.

steps.headline: Add the stick of celery (whole or halved) to the pan.
steps.description: It will be removed at the end and the best taste comes from the leaves.

steps.headline: Add half a tablespoon of Worcester sauce, bay leaf and stir well.
steps.description: Taste a small amount of the sauce and add salt to your taste.

steps.headline: Turn the heat up and bring the ingredients to the boil.
steps.description: Then turn the heat down to low until the sauce is simmering. Cover the pan and cook for at least 90 minutes.

steps.headline: Return to the pan every 20-30 minutes to give it a good stir and keep an eye on the level of liquid - if it goes too low add more water or the ingredients will burn.
steps.description: The casserole is ready when the sauce is thick enough to stick to the spoon, and when the meat is soft - for the best results cook for 2 hours or more

steps.headline: Remove the celery from the pan and serve the casserole in large bowls or plates with crusty bread.

text: Peel and dice the onion and the garlic in to fine cubes  Chop the mushrooms in half lengthways (or if using small mushrooms you can leave them whole)  Place your pan on a medium heat, with a tablespoon of cooking oil in it. When the oil is moderately hot (see tips below), add the onion and garlic to the pan. Stir the onion and garlic until they appear light brown and feel soft with the end of the spoon.  Add the meat and spread it evenly around the pan. Stir this occasionally for the next 5 minutes. The aim is to seal the meat so it looks darker on the outside. Drain the water from the can of beans and add them to the pan, with the mushrooms and any other vegetables you are using. Stir for 1 minute. Add the stock and red wine to the pan. Ideally the liquid should only just cover all of the ingredients but you can top it up with cold water if not. Add the stick of celery (whole or halved) to the pan. It will be removed at the end and the best taste comes from the leaves. Add half a tablespoon of Worcester sauce, bay leaf and stir well. Taste a small amount of the sauce and add salt to your taste. Turn the heat up and bring the ingredients to the boil. Then turn the heat down to low until the sauce is simmering. Cover the pan and cook for at least 90 minutes. Return to the pan every 20-30 minutes to give it a good stir and keep an eye on the level of liquid - if it goes too low add more water or the ingredients will burn. The casserole is ready when the sauce is thick enough to stick to the spoon, and when the meat is soft - for the best results cook for 2 hours or more Remove the celery from the pan and serve the casserole in large bowls or plates with crusty bread.  Finished.
